Fields.DialogueText: How are we doing out here, crewman?
Oh! Captain! Doing quite well, I should say.
Glad to see the weather hasn't dampened your spirits. Keeping a sharp eye?
I do my best, Captain. Wouldn't do to smash against a rock while I'm on lookout, would it?
Sawubona. Room for one more up here?
Plenty of room, Zulu. Come on in.
Cup of hot tea? It can get cold outside on the weatherdecks when the wind picks up, no matter the season.

Fields.MenuText: Thanks! Tea sounds perfect.
Quite thoughtful of you.
Oh. You drink tea?

Fields.DialogueText: As it should.
More than a simple kindness, Captain.
Why wouldn't I?
And of course, one for the lookout. A simple duty, but an important one nonetheless.
Er, yeah, thanks for the cup... Ma'am.
I sense that I might be needed elsewhere. By your leave, Captain.
Certainly, Zulu. I'll see you at the operations meeting.
Everything all right now, Cap?
Nothing to worry about. Keep a sharp eye until the end of your watch.
Aye-aye, Captain. I'll sing out if I spot anything at all.
@BATTLE
Why aren't you drinking it? Don't you like it?
Ah, yes.... mmmm... delicious....
*ALARM*
Commendable performance in our last fight, Zulu. Excellent work.
Thank you, Captain. Get my guns in range, and I'll give any target regrets about tangling with us.
Was there something else on your mind, Captain?
It's relatively minor - but, yes. Remember when you brought tea up to the lookout...

Fields.MenuText: The lookout seemed uncomfortable around you.
You seemed uncomfortable around the lookout.
Is something wrong that I need to know about?

Fields.DialogueText: You sensed it, too? I was hoping it wouldn't be a persistent problem, but...
I'm fine. I was trying to make the lookout more comfortable around me...
I have some concerns about my ability to integrate with the crew...
... but I'm not certain the situation is improving.
I don't want friction between you and the crew. Can you tell me more about it?
That discussion might take a bit of time, Captain.
We might have--
*ALARM*
--to try this another time.
I suppose so. Let's get to battle stations, Zulu.
@BATTLE
Captain! Captain! Do you smell that?
Slow down! I don't want to get run over on my own ship!
Apologies, Cap - but you need to know what's going on in the galley.
Is there a fire? I didn't hear an announcement. Is everybody all right?
Er, no, nothing quite like that... Lady Zulu told the cooks to change the plans for the next meal!
I'm not ready to panic yet, but keep going. She changed the plans to what, exactly?
Liver! Liver and onions!

Fields.MenuText: Liver is good for you. Moreover, fussing over something like this is childish.
If you ask me, I like liver and onions.
YUCK!

Fields.DialogueText: And I hoped leaving home to join the Royal Navy would get me away from being told to eat my supper...
She's getting in your head, Captain!
My thoughts exactly, Captain!
I'm still trying to see how this stands as a matter of importance.
Zulu is doing this to us because she... she...
Because she what?
Surely you've heard the rumors, Cap... about the liver.
I've heard just about enough of this, and I've got half a mind to send you to sick bay right now if you don't snap out of it.
Sick bay? But I...
But you *what?*
Now that I think of it, I'd appreciate if you disregarded my remarks about Lady Zulu and the ship's menu.
*ALARM*
Good choice. Get to your battle station.
Yes, Captain. By your leave!
@BATTLE
What was that?
Er, nothing. Sorry, Cap.
What?
Liver!
And, for the record, I will come down like the wrath of God on any crew member who suggests the ship's Belle is doing nefarious things with liver.
It's not just disrespectful, it's stupid enough to embarrass us in front of other crews. Got it?
A man overboard? A broken leg? An outbreak of polio!
No. None of those things.
An explosion in munitions storage, then? We need damage control and medical response immediately!
No.
Right. Of course not. I supposed I would have sensed that. Quickly, tell me how I can help.
At ease, Zulu. The crew is perfectly safe.
They are? Good... but then you've got me at a loss, Captain. Why do you look so concerned? I presumed something's wrong.

Fields.MenuText: Do you always worry about the crew's safety?
I don't often say this, but: just this once, you don't have to be paranoid.
Expecting things to go wrong is probably the best way to survive in wartime.

Fields.DialogueText: Forgive me for answering one question with another, but would a mother stop caring for her children?
I'd say I'm simply aware of the many dangers we could face.
You see the wisdom of it, then. Good.
My duty is nothing less than total responsibility for our sailors.
Good to know.
That said, I'd still like to know why you wear that expression on your face, Captain.
I can't believe I'm saying this, but... I think we ought to talk about the liver.
Liver?
Yes, liver. One of our personnel told me in confidence that you demanded to change the ship's menu to serve liver for dinner, and apparently that's cause for concern. Is there something I'm missing--
HA HA HA! Liver?! HA HA HA!
Zulu?
HAHAHAHAHAHAHA! And onions, too! Liver and onions!
Um...
Ah. Hurry with me to the bridge, Captain. I sense a Morgana presence approaching our position.
@BATTLE
Ohhhhhh, my. Heh.
Scratch all enemy contacts. We have a clear horizon again!
Impressive work, Lady Zulu. You've zeroed your guns in record time.
Doing my best, Captain.
Ah... time for a debrief, just you and me?
Debrief? Are you still going on about that liver thing?

Fields.MenuText: Are you sure everything is all right?
You were laughing like a maniac, you know.
On second thought, we really don't need to debrief. Forget I mentioned it.

Fields.DialogueText: I can read the damage reports again if you'd like.
Oh, that... I can explain.
I don't mind talking to you about it in confidence, Captain.
It's no secret that some of the crew is apprehensive around me. They aren't sure how to react to a Zulu woman, but I'm a British citizen, too.
It's so ridiculous it's almost funny. Apparently someone started a rumor that eating liver was part of a tribal ritual. A very twitchy minority saw that menu as the first step toward paganism.
It's not almost funny, Captain. It *is* funny! Liver and onions is a traditional English dish, too!
Seriously, though - are you all right? "Funny" is one thing, but your reaction was... a little extreme.
Extreme?
In a word, yes.
I won't come unglued, Captain. I promise. When it comes to keeping the crew safe, I'll gather my wits quickly and see things through.
I'll hold you to your word on that one.
I promise. You can count on me. In fact... yes... we've got incoming!
@BATTLE
Not exactly what I meant.
Oh. That.
I wonder what they'd say if I started serving pints of bitter.

Fields.MenuText: Let's not find out.
In my experience, sailors are generally unlikely to complain about alcohol.
If they couldn't fault the beer, they'd find something wrong with the glasses.

Fields.DialogueText: No. Of course not.
Maybe that's the key to a better world.
You've obviously never been in a pub at lights out.
*sigh*
All supplies aboard, Captain. Fuel and ammunition topped off. Consumables are being stowed as we speak.
Great news, Lieutenant. Let's make it last.
Aye-aye, Captain.
Speaking of stowage, the crew left a half-empty box outside my door. Make sure that one gets stowed, too.
That's no gear adrift, Cap. The supply ship had some sundries for us, and that box is yours.
Oh. As long as the crew got some, too.
I made sure of it.
Sawubona to you both! Oh, I'm feeling so full...
We just finished loading our supplies. You've got a full tank, Lady Zulu.
That explains it, then.
I'm off then. By your leave, Captain.
Of course.
Oh! What's this box doing here?
Some extra things from the supply ship, according to the lieutenant. I haven't opened it yet.
Mind if I take a look?

Fields.MenuText: Hands off, Zulu! That's my stuff!
Probably just some junk, but you never know.
Help yourself.

Fields.DialogueText: I only asked to look, not to loot. Relax!
That's right! You never know!
Well, if you insist....
All right, then. Have a look.
Oh! How curious...
What's in the box, Zulu?
*ALARM*
Morganas! Let's go!
Can't you just tell me on the way to battle stations?
First things first, Captain!
@BATTLE
*KNOCK*
Mind if I come in, Zulu?
Sawubona! My door is always open for my Captain. Come on in!
I haven't seen your quarters before. Cozy in here.
Thank you, Captain. Did you finally open the box that the crew brought for you from the supply ship?
I did. It was...

Fields.MenuText: ... a few dusty books and a wool scarf. A little bit odd, but I wasn't expecting much.
... chock full of gold doubloons! I'm retiring from the service to become landed gentry in the English countryside.
... just a few small picture frames for my desk.

Fields.DialogueText: At least the crew showed respect by thinking of you, Captain. That's what matters.
HA! You have a curious sense of humour, Captain!
It's the thought that counts, isn't it?
My box was small, but I was happy to find small picture frames inside. I plan to frame some photos of my sisters.
Sisters? You mean the other destroyers in the Tribal class?
Oh, yes. I consider the entire class my sisters, but especially Cossack and Nubian. I wish I could see them more....
Do you feel like family here, Zulu?
Yes. Now ask the crew how they feel.
Well, they did bring you a box of sundries, right?
That's true. Maybe things will get better.
@BATTLE
So I'm always told. What of you, Zulu? Did you get something?
*ALARM*
Torpedo five and torpedo six are away! Both running hot and straight, Captain.
Very well, lieutenant.
Can't we switch to guns?
Don't get frustrated, Zulu. Execute the orders and make your best shots.
I'm better with guns.

Fields.MenuText: We won't improve if we don't keep trying, Lady Zulu.
Unless I'm mistaken, HQ made me captain of a destroyer. I'd like to be able to destroy something today.
Your recommendation is acknowledged, Lady Zulu, but we're still shooting torpedoes.

Fields.DialogueText: Yes, Captain.
Hmph!
Yes, Captain.
Tracking our shots, but looks like we're off the mark. Two more misses, Cap.
Very well.
Again.
Reloading tubes...
Oh, something doesn't feel right...
Chin up, Zulu. It's only target practice. Be glad that-
*ALARM*
Contacts on the horizon, Cap! Looks like our target practice became the real thing!
Here we go!
@BATTLE
In the engine room? I can't recall seeing you down here before.
Behold! Feast your eyes on this rarest of sights, Captain! The Ship's Lady walks among you in the engine room!
Should I clap?
Sorry if I got carried away. Actually, my presence here serves a routine purpose. The seawater strainers often clog with debris, and they need to be cleaned now and then.

Fields.MenuText: A room of British shipbuilders are no match for real world conditions.
That's well and good, but I'm concerned about your morale.
Convince me that you're holding up. The crew doesn't always make it easy.

Fields.DialogueText: No cause for concern. I'm built to serve in almost any theatre of war, Captain.
I didn't mean to let my frustration show, Captain. I'll work to improve that.
I'll admit some truth to that.
I do get troubled by the crew's opinion of me. They still step lightly in my presence.
Is that why you're back here in the engine room?
I'm not hiding... at least I don't think I am.
When you're done with those strainers, get up to the radio room. You've got a message waiting for you.
Oh? I'll hurry up then! Ngiyabonga, Captain!
You did just say ''Thank you,'' right?
HA! Yes, yes I did.
Make it fast. You never know when the next Morgana with a bad attitude will come over the horizon.
Aye-aye!
@BATTLE
*ALARM*
Well? How were those messages?
Gratifying. Nubian and Cossack were just checking in.
*sigh*

Fields.MenuText: Worried?
Relieved?
Headache?

Fields.DialogueText: I always worry, but no. This is a relief.
A bit.
HA! No, Captain. Not in the least.
Look in my heart for fear of my own safety, and you will find none. My sisters or my crew, however, are another matter.
It just... it always does me good to hear their engines are running and their hulls are intact.
I've got two siblings in the RAF. I understand that feeling, Lady Zulu.
Then do this for me. Send them a message, and tell them your Belle fights to make certain their brother will come home safe.
I... I'll do that. Thank you, ma'am.
I have a bit of gardening to do. Thanks again!
I think you just made her day.
Back to work. After you transmit that message, of course.
Aye-aye, Captain!
@BATTLE
*ALARM*
You look thirsty, Captain.
I do?
Yes, quite. In fact, I happen to have exactly what you need! Ready?

Fields.MenuText: Parched, even. What have you got for me?
Whatever you say.
This conversation sounds just a little bit creepy...

Fields.DialogueText: Put out your hands, and I'll show you.
O! Great Fortune smiles upon me, blessing me with such a compliant and enthusiastic leader!
Oh, don't fuss.
Just take this cup and try a sip of this. I just brewed it.
Down the hatch... *sip*
Wow! That's some strong black tea!
Annnnnd?
I smell... lemongrass, I think.
I've been growing some in a small herb garden in my cabin and then paired it with some whole-leaf African tea. What do you think?
Will the crew like it? Am I trying too hard?
Great, yes, and maybe. In that order.
Captain, I love tea.
You're most welcome. And now I'm off!
Morganas?
No, Captain. I'm heading to the galley so the cooks can share some of my tea with the crew!
Glad I could be your guinea pig, Lady Zulu.
@BATTLE
*ALARM*
Clearly.
Most of the British crew loves tea.
I'll take you at your word.
This is a pleasure I can share, and that excites me. I'm not naive about what I can accomplish here, but... tea!
Heh. Understood. And thanks for the cuppa.
Need something to eat, Cap? The cooks got some leftovers lying about if you're peckish.
Just walking about and inspecting the ship, but thank you.
Oh...
What is it?
I've just got to ask, Captain. Did you try it yet, Cap? That tea Lady Zulu put in the galley?

Fields.MenuText: I did. Good, isn't it?
Yes - but I couldn't really compare it to anything else. I'm not much of a tea-drinker.
NO! It's cursed tribal African tea! It will turn you into a frog if you drink it!

Fields.DialogueText: May not replace my Earl Grey, but it was nice.
That's a good one! Shall I take the Union Jack down from our yardarm as well?
Damn! I wonder how much time I've got left before my transformation begins! A shame really... I liked the taste of it...
Honestly, Cap, a few chaps hesitated to drink it. One even joked that maybe she made it from the ground bones of her ancestors or some such nonsense...
...but it's just a good, honest cup of black tea with a spot of lemongrass in it to freshen it up.
Puns, Captain? I heard that!
*ALARM*
And that...
@BATTLE
Oh, come on!

Fields.MenuText: Indeed it is... no BONES about it... right?
Well said.

Fields.DialogueText: It's actually nice to be able to just talk about tea, innit? The war gets in the way of so much else, but--
*ALARM*
Son of a--
Captain on the bridge!
Very well, Lieutenant. Give me your report.
Infrequent sonar contact on ASDIC of a German U-boat.
I'm listening as hard as I can.
Visual contact, off the port beam.
Did the U-boat surface?
No, Captain. Those are Morganas.

Fields.MenuText: Zulu, what are your thoughts?
Radio the sub and politely request her assistance.
Part of me wishes we could evade and let them kill each other.

Fields.DialogueText: The Zurich Treaty is clear, Captain. In the presence of Morganas, we unify our efforts.
By the terms of the Zurich Treaty, she is obligated to assist... but we can't count on it.
We can't run from Morganas, Captain!
Do you trust that German submarine won't shoot us in the back while we fight?
No choice, Lieutenant.
They may be an honorable crew. And if not, how will they learn without a good example to follow?
Guns up, Lady Zulu. Fill all Morgana ships with holes.
Aye-aye, Captain.
@BATTLE
She's right, Captain.
I'm completely aware of that, Lieutenant; that's the nature of a test.
Still at it?
Listening as hard as I can. Without my guns firing at Morganas, the relative silence makes using sonar a lot easier.
Call everybody back to the bridge if you get any hints of that U-boat again.
Aye-aye, Captain. I will.
The Germans can try to hide from us under the waves, but we're well-designed to find them.
Funny, isn't it? Ever since the Americans tried to use the Turtle against us to break blockades, submarines carried a sinister reputation.
Even when we launched our own years later, the head of the Royal Navy himself, Admiral Wilson, said submarines were "underhanded, unfair and damned un-English"...
We've come a long way since the 18th century. And I don't just mean submarine design.
Enemies becoming friends? We're staunch allies with the Americans now, and I hope it stays that way.
Me, too.
Oh! I hear something!
The U-boat?
No... Morganas!
@BATTLE
Setting aside the more general concerns - is this thing supposed to be out here? I don't recall any Fleet instructions saying we could expect company.
No, but radio contact has been spotty. And if the U-boat is lost or--
That's it for the debrief. Lieutenant, draft the after-action report and I'll review it once that's done.
Aye-aye, Captain. I'll get to work on it.
I'm learning your expressions, Captain. Gradually, mind you, but I'm learning them.
And what, pray tell, does the one on my face say?
You had a question for me, but I think it's a good one.

Fields.MenuText: Would you believe I'm just fighting some indigestion?
I compared shots fired to confirmed hits. Your accuracy's up, and I'm curious why.
Can I get more of that Zulu tea?

Fields.DialogueText: HA! You can't fool me that easily, Captain.
And to think I believed you hadn't noticed!
Why? So that you can fight better, too? You should know that it wasn't the tea.
Cossack and Nubian shared some of their experiences from their own encounters with me, their younger sister.
It seems to be helping me in combat, getting my turrets moving a bit more effectively now.
Oh, plus I learned a few tricks with ASDIC that might help hunt submarines better, sorting out the background noise to focus on the right signals.
Leaders share their experiences. Glad to see Belles do the same.
We have our different styles, but we are sisters. British in our own ways.
*ALARM*
And a Morgana is a Morgana is a Morgana...
@BATTLE
Of course not! So....
Sawubona! What brings you to my cabin, Captain?
I was thinking about what you said before, about your sisters. It inspired me to put a message out to all other Tribal-class ships.
Really? I hope they have some insights for us.
I included some of our reports as well. Maybe our experiences could help them, too.
I'd be so proud of that!
Not all of them have Belles, of course.
That's right.
I was wondering something, Zulu. What about other Tribal-class destroyers?

Fields.MenuText: Are they your sisters, too?
Do you think they have Belles waiting to appear?
Are they less effective in combat?

Fields.DialogueText: I'm closest to Cossack and Nubian, but I consider them all my family.
I'd love to think so!
Without speaking ill of the others, I'd say ships with Belles will always be more effective.
That reminds me! Remember those picture frames we got from the supply ship? I've started putting up pictures of my sisters.
Done anything with yours, Captain?
Not yet. You have a lot of sisters, so if you need some of my frames you're welcome to them.
Thanks! Ngiyabonga, Captain! Though, that may have to wait!
@BATTLE
*ALARM*
Hot from the radio room, Lady Zulu.
What's the news?
Is this the priority message the messenger told me about?
Yes, Captain.
We'll take it from here.
Oh! This message!

Fields.MenuText: Something good?
Something bad?
Does it say liver and onions for supper again tonight?

Fields.DialogueText: You could call it that!
On the contrary!
If we want to celebrate, then yes!
The message from HQ reports that another Tribal-class destroyer participated in a major victory over Morgana forces!
I don't recall ever seeing flash priority to send something like this before.
Maybe not, but it's a good way to boost morale. I think our fleets will take heart hearing about the victory.
And that my sisters were so capable! I'm proud of them all right now.
And maybe...
Maybe what? Maybe we'll win the war?
Not that...
Then what?
Never mind. Yes, of course. That we win the war.
Oh.
*ALARM*
Then let's show everybody what a Belle's Tribal-class destroyer can do right now. Come on, Zulu.
Aye-aye, Captain.
@BATTLE
Captain, another priority message from HQ. It says tha--
Sawubona, Lieutenant.
Er, hello.
You said we have another message?
It's marked for command's eyes only, Lady Zulu.

Fields.MenuText: It's fine.
A formality, Zulu. You know I'll debrief you on the contents once I've read it.
A bit presumptive, Zulu, don't you think?

Fields.DialogueText: On second thought, I should wait.
Right. I suppose I jumped the gun.
You're right.
Apologies. I'm needed in...
... in the, uh, engine room. I've got to check... something. Urgently.
The message, Captain?
Right. I'll take it to my cabin, Lieutenant.
You got it, Captain.
Okay, folks. Take a deep breath and let's go.
@BATTLE
Why the long face, Zulu? Are we out of lemongrass tea?
Can we speak in private?
Over a joke? It was dumb, but I'm not sure what I can do to help you out.
You seemed enthusiastic about that message, the one about your sisters, but now you seem more dejected than I've ever seen you.
That's what I'd like to speak about, if you have a moment. When that message came out, I felt something.

Fields.MenuText: Are you afraid you won't live up to your sisters? I don't think you need to worry about that.
Are you worried about them being involved in such a dangerous operation? They came through in one piece, you know.
I'm listening.

Fields.DialogueText: Your confidence is reassuring, but that's not quite what has me concerned.
We all face danger, Captain, and I'm not afraid to die, though I'd do anything to keep our crew safe.
Ngiyabonga, Captain. I'll do my best to explain.
It's an honour to serve as a Royal Navy vessel. It always has been.
Remember the crew's reaction to having liver for supper? I was trying to choose something quintessentially English, but some of them panicked.
I'm sure you heard the rumour that I was trying to cast a spell on them.
So, yes, when HQ publicly lauded someone else's success, I secretly hoped they would do the same for us and the crew would see us as countrymen.
Not really, no.
Don't give up, Zulu.
I won't.
*ALARM*
Especially not now. Always ready to fight, Captain.
@BATTLE
But that hasn't materialized, has it?
But it... I think it's still the case that some of the crew thinks it's unearned. Or that I'm a kind of accident. Not really British, you know?
Actually, I think I told people to shut up and stop embarrassing us all before they got to the specific insane hypothesis. But, sorry, carry on.
Ha. Thank you, Captain.
Nobody's come out and said they hope the Royal Navy will rename me after some village in the Lake District just to see what would happen, but I can't help but think it wouldn't be unwelcome.
It's getting worse.
What's getting worse?
How many times do I have to shoot Morganas full of holes before the crew stops thinking that... that...
That what?

Fields.MenuText: That you're not a capable warship?
That you're not truly British?
Just take a deep breath and then talk me through it.

Fields.DialogueText: No, that's not it.
Exactly!
Yes. It's... ugh.
In a way, it's about the Empire itself. Look at how proud they are! The names they gave to my sisters and me!
The whole Tribal class, different lands and cultures... and we all fight their wars for them.
Them?
I would say "us," but I don't really feel like they want me so much.
Listen, you're a tea-drinking Brit as much as anyone, as far as I'm concerned. Lemongrass or not.
I appreciate that sentiment, Captain. That helps a little, but it's still a struggle.
I have something for you to consider. Do you ever think about...
*ALARM*
Damn...
Another time, Lady Zulu. For now, chin up.
And keep a stiff upper lip.
Exactly.
@BATTLE
... You remember I was joking the other day about having my name changed to that of some village in the Lake District? Apparently word of that got out.
Within twenty-four hours there was a group passionately embracing the idea that I could be HMS Ravenglass. For all I know, they're writing their MPs to suggest it right now.
... Would you be willing to give me names?
Of course not.
Right. Just thought I'd ask.
And, just to be clear, they told me about it. It wasn't malicious. Just, "Wouldn't it be great?" as though I'd naturally agree that me being Zulu was a problem worth solving.
Heavy gunfire from starboard, Captain.
We haven't silenced all of these Morganas yet.
So many of them...
Those on the flank are trying us hard. Get us about, Zulu. Hard rudder.
Already on it! Good luck with taking a piece of me, Morganas!

Fields.MenuText: Make a good impression on our targets, Zulu.
Enjoying yourself?
Easy does it. I need level heads in this fight.

Fields.DialogueText: With pleasure!
Absolutely!
I won't get carried away, Captain.
Get a good look at that Morgana, crew, while its still above water. Now let's take them down!
@BATTLE
Where have you been? I wanted you in my cabin right away, Zulu.
Sawubona, Captain. I had the cooks put a kettle on, thinking maybe we could have some tea with our discussion.
You stopped by the galley first?
A brief stop.

Fields.MenuText: Right away means right away, Zulu.
Thoughtful of you.
Are you going to have a tea service when you get court-martialed, too?

Fields.DialogueText: Apologies, Captain.
I thought it might help things go smoothly. Show you that everything is fine.
What?! I didn't think it was that serious.
I blew off a little bit of steam while we were fighting. I'm not losing my mind, Captain.
Combat can take a heavy toll. I just wanted to make sure you were all right.
Better than ever. I just made a conscious decision to be seen by the crew.
Seen? They see you all the time.
They just have to see more of me.
Hiding traditions, avoiding Zulu words, not talking about my sisters... that just leaves room for all of the unspoken thoughts and suspicions.
I'm a Brit as much as the rest of them, and they'll see it.
Are you sure that's the right way to approach this?
With all respect, Captain, please consider my performance in the last combat. Any errors? Missed orders? Problems with combat effectiveness?
I can't argue with that. But, so you know, I'm willing to just go out there and shout at the ones who are being idiots.
*ALARM*
I think you have bigger targets, Captain.
@BATTLE
Torpedoes running hot and straight.
Almost in range with the guns, but we can get a few more fish in the water while we close range.
Doing my best, Lady Zulu.
Need any help? I could summon my ancestral spirits if your torpedo crews need a few extra hands to reload the launcher.
Excuse me?
I just need a few chicken bones and a few drops of your blood. Run down to the galley. They've got bones and a lot of knives.
WHAT?!
I'll keep an eye on your station for you, but hurry back.
Err, Captain?

Fields.MenuText: Zulu, focus on the torpedoes!
Don't push the Lieutenant too hard.
Zulu, I don't know the protocol. Do you need me to drum or put on a ceremonial mask or something?

Fields.DialogueText: Aye-aye, Captain. Thirty seconds until calculated impact.
Why, is he fragile?
Just have a ceremonial spear handy.
I get it, Captain. Zulu is just breaking a little tension.
That's one way of putting it.
We're fine here, Captain. Oh, and ten seconds left on the torpedoes.
I could really use a hit here...
*BOOM*
Direct hits on the dummies, Captain. Shall we continue the drill?
Belay that, Lieutenant, we've got juicier targets inbound.
@BATTLE
*ALARM*
Tell us again exactly what we're drinking?
I know the words are hard to remember until you hear them a few times, but this is utywala.
If you were listening harder, Lieutenant, you'd know the important part. It's got alcohol in it.
I should correct myself. It's not exactly the same thing as the old Zulu recipe. I just took a few ingredients, and brewed it like an India pale ale.
It doesn't taste too different, really. Take a sip, Lieutenant. Your Irish tongue should be able to handle it.
I'll prove you right on that one, sailor. Hand me that jug.
Oh! Captain on deck.

Fields.MenuText: Too late to cover my eyes and ignore this flagrant fraternization?
Making some changes to the grog ration today?
I've intruded on some fun. Time for a tactical retreat to my cabin.

Fields.DialogueText: I was just sharing a traditional drink with the crew, celebrating the victory.
A small change, but nothing the queen would frown upon.
Nonsense, Captain.
No harm in it. Glad to see everybody in good spirits.
The operative word, my friends, is "spirits" - so now let's try a little more.
It's not a heavy drink, Captain. I promise I won't let them get into trouble.
I appreciate that. And I trust you'll take good care of them, Lady Zulu.
@BATTLE
Too good to drink with a trio of Brits?
*ALARM*
Hope you don't mind the intrusion.
No intrusion at all. If I remember correctly, I told you my cabin would always welcome a visit.
And if I remember correctly, your words were "Anybody brave enough is welcome to try coming through my cabin door."
I may have phrased it that way...
You know I'm not trying to pick a fight with anybody in the crew! Just a bit of friendly bravado, you understand.
What a relief. It'd be a shame to court-martial a Belle.
HA! I'm glad you get the joke.
You've always had courage, Zulu, but now...
Now what?

Fields.MenuText: Now you're... bold.
You're still the same Zulu.
I sense true confidence.

Fields.DialogueText: Bold? I would put it a different way.
The same old Zulu.
Confidence? I've always been confident.
I'm just a little more comfortable. And I can do more for the crew, because they are more comfortable around me.
I'm glad to hear that. Ready for the mission brief in a little bit?
I'll see you there. If you get there first, put a kettle on?
And if you get there first, do the same for me.
Aye-aye, Captain. See you there.
Zulu's finally got her feet beneath her. Her confidence...

Fields.MenuText: ... makes her somebody I could trust with anything.
... makes her attractive, if I'm honest with myself.
